      <title>UK water companies receive record sewage leak fines</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/uk-water-companies-receive-record-sewage-leak-fines</link>
      <description><p>Firms face tougher penalties aimed at reducing the number of pollution offences</p><p>Water companies have been hit by a series of record fines for major sewage leaks and other pollution incidents.</p><p>Yorkshire Water was fined £1.1m for illegally discharging sewage that polluted the river Ouse near York, while Thames Water was fined £1m for repeated sewage leaks into the Grand Union canal. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/uk-water-companies-receive-record-sewage-leak-fines">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Air pollution rising at an 'alarming rate' in world's cities</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities</link>
      <description><p>Outdoor pollution has risen 8% in five years with fast-growing cities in the developing world worst affected, WHO data shows</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you?</a><br></li></ul><p><br>Outdoor air pollution has grown 8% globally in the past five years, with billions of people around the world now exposed to dangerous air, <a href="http://www.who.int/phe">according to new data</a> from more than 3,000 cities compiled by the World Health Organisation (WHO). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-rising-at-an-alarming-rate-in-worlds-cities">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Subsidy U-turn clouds future of major Scottish windfarm</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/subsidy-u-turn-clouds-future-of-major-scottish-windfarm</link>
      <description><p>Developers of an offshore windfarm planned in the Forth estuary have taken legal action after vital subsidies were withdrawn</p><p>The future of one of the UK’s biggest proposed offshore windfarms has been thrown into doubt by a row over the government support it should receive.</p><p>The <a href="http://www.neartnagaoithe.com/">Neart na Gaoithe</a> windfarm, based in Scotland’s outer Forth estuary, would have a capacity of about 450MW of power and was originally planned to cost £1.4bn to build, though that is likely to rise to more than £2bn.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/subsidy-u-turn-clouds-future-of-major-scottish-windfarm">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Bill  and Melinda Gates Foundation divests entire holding in BP</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/bill-and-melinda-gates-foundation-divests-entire-holding-in-bp</link>
      <description><p>World’s largest health charity sells its $187m stake in the oil giant in a move welcomed by fossil fuel divestment campaigners</p><p>The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation has sold off its entire holding in oil giant BP, in a move welcomed by fossil fuel divestment campaigners.<br></p><p>Bill Gates has called the selling off of coal, oil and gas stocks a “<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/oct/14/bill-gates-calls-fossil-fuel-divestment-a-false-solution">false solution</a>” to climate change, but the known investments of his foundation in major fossil fuel companies has fallen by 85% since 2014.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/bill-and-melinda-gates-foundation-divests-entire-holding-in-bp">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How scared or hopeful should we be in a warming world? | Clive Hamilton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/how-scared-or-hopeful-should-we-be-in-a-warming-world</link>
      <description><p>Should we be optimistic that the Paris agreement can save us from serious climate change or is it too little too late? <a href="https://theconversation.com/how-scared-or-hopeful-should-we-be-in-a-warming-world-59314">Clive Hamilton</a> looks at both sides of the debate</p><p>For anyone who takes notice of the climate change debate, a mass of often-contradictory information comes flooding into our lives. Some of it prompts great alarm. The Great Barrier Reef is suffering severe bleaching. Wild fires are consuming Alberta. Last year was the warmest on record, and 15 of the 16 hottest years on record have occurred since 2001.</p><p>Yet there are also some positive signs that the world is at last getting serious about the threat. Global investment in renewable energy last year exceeded investment in fossil energy for the first time. Coal use in the United States is <a href="http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/04/29/3774027/coal-use-declining/?utm_source=newsletter&amp;amp;utm_medium=email&amp;amp;utm_campaign=cptop3&amp;amp;utm_term=1&amp;amp;utm_content=53">falling</a> rapidly. China has <a href="http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2016/01/04/3735798/china-bans-new-coal/">stopped</a> approving new coalmines. And the Paris Agreement of December 2015 was hailed as a breakthrough, a turning point in the battle.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/how-scared-or-hopeful-should-we-be-in-a-warming-world">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Great Barrier Reef: devastating images tell story of coral colonies' destruction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-devastating-images-tell-story-of-coral-colonies-destruction</link>
      <description><p><strong>Exclusive:</strong> a series of images taken from around Lizard Island reveal the rapid death of coral across thousands of kilometres of the reef as bleaching takes hold</p><p>Devastating images showing the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/19/great-barrier-reef-93-of-reefs-hit-by-coral-bleaching">complete destruction of coral colonies on the Great Barrier Reef</a> have been obtained by Guardian Australia and illustrate what is happening to coral there that would fill an area the size of Scotland.</p><p>They reveal the rapid death of coral impacting much of the Great Barrier Reef, with estimates that as much as half of the coral in the northern third of the 2000km reef had this fate.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-devastating-images-tell-story-of-coral-colonies-destruction">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/why-is-climate-champion-richard-branson-allowing-deniers-on-a-virgin-podcast</link>
      <description><p>Despite more than 90% of experts agreeing on the science, listeners hear incorrect and ridiculous claims from James Delingpole - all ‘in the interest of balance’ </p><p>Aside from the facial hair and the petrol-guzzling international airline, one thing Virgin founder Sir Richard Branson is known for is his passion for fighting climate change.</p><p>“We need every person on Earth to acknowledge that climate change is real, and encourage each other and our leaders to address the challenge,” <a href="https://www.virgin.com/richard-branson/climate-change-is-real-0">wrote billionaire Branson</a> last year. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/why-is-climate-champion-richard-branson-allowing-deniers-on-a-virgin-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>28% of US bees wiped out this winter, suggesting bigger environmental issues</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/bee-colony-deaths-environmental-problems</link>
      <description><p>More than half of beekeepers suffered unsustainable losses, with deadly mite infestations and harmful land management practices piling on pressure</p><p>More than a quarter of American honeybee colonies were wiped out over the winter, with deadly infestations of mites and harmful land management practices heaping mounting pressure upon the crucial pollinators and the businesses that keep them.<br></p><p>Preliminary figures commissioned by the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) <a href="https://beeinformed.org/results/colony-loss-2015-2016-preliminary-results/">show that 28% of bee colonies in the United States</a> were lost over the 2015-16 winter. More than half of surveyed beekeepers said they suffered unsustainable losses during the winter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/bee-colony-deaths-environmental-problems">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/bees">Bees</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/environment">Environment</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/insects">Insects</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/wildlife">Wildlife</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/animals">Animals</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/science/agriculture">Agriculture</category>

    <item>
      <title>Unprecedented 'red tide' crisis deepens in Chile's fishing-rich waters</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/red-tide-crisis-deepens-in-chile-fishing-waters</link>
      <description><p>The ‘<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/03/chile-fishermen-red-tide-algal-bloom-protests">red tide</a>’ algal bloom, which turns the sea water red and makes seafood toxic, is believed to be one of the country’s worst recent environmental crises </p><p>A “red tide” outbreak is widening in southern Chile’s fishing-rich waters, the government has said, deepening what is already believed to be one of the country’s worst environmental crises in recent years.</p><p> The red tide – <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/03/chile-fishermen-red-tide-algal-bloom-protests">an algal bloom that turns the seawater red and makes seafood toxic</a> – is a common, naturally recurring phenomenon in southern Chile, but the extent of the current outbreak is unprecedented.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/11/red-tide-crisis-deepens-in-chile-fishing-waters">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Reeling it in: global sustainable seafood market hits $11.5bn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/11/seafood-industry-sustainable-fishing-salmon-overfishing</link>
      <description><p>A new report shows that demand for seafood with sustainable certification now accounts for 14% of the global market – up from less than 1% a decade ago</p><p>The global sustainable seafood market hit $11.5bn in retail sales last year, a result of commitments by large restaurant chains and retailers such<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/walmart-sustainable-seafood-alaskan-salmon"> as Walmart</a>, Whole Foods, Ikea and McDonald’s to source certified seafood and address decades of mismanagement, according to <a href="http://www.iisd.org/ssi/standards-and-the-blue-economy/">a report</a> released today.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/01/palau-sustainable-fishing-protect-endangered-marine-life">Off the hook: can a new study in the Pacific reel in unsustainable fishing?</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/may/11/seafood-industry-sustainable-fishing-salmon-overfishing">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/canada-wildfire-environmental-impacts-fort-mcmurray</link>
      <description><p>In addition to the estimated $9bn damage to Fort McMurray, ‘the beast’ will affect forests, carbon emissions, air and water pollution and waste </p><p>The explosive wildfire in Canada’s tar sands region that forced 90,000 people to flee last week is still burning. By Tuesday, “the beast” had grown to 230,000 hectares, but had moved into largely unpopulated regions east and south of the town of Fort McMurray, Alberta. </p><p>Although officials have found 80-90% of the town undamaged, power and water is out, and about 2,400 homes and other buildings have been burned down. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/canada-wildfire-environmental-impacts-fort-mcmurray">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>UN climate science chief: it's not too late to avoid dangerous temperature rise</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/un-climate-change-hoesung-lee-global-warming-interview</link>
      <description><p>Hoesung Lee, head of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, voices hope in battle against 2C increase in warming but warns of ‘phenomenal’ costs</p><p>The head of the United Nations climate science panel has declared it is still possible to avoid a dangerous 2C increase in global warming – despite more than a dozen record hot years since 2000. But the costs could be “phenomenal”, he said.</p><p>In an interview with the Guardian, Hoesung Lee, the leader of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), defied the bleak outlook of climate scientists who warn the world is hurtling to a 2C rise far faster than anticipated.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/un-climate-change-hoesung-lee-global-warming-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Power cuts caused by flooding 'major danger' to British lives, engineers warn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/power-cuts-caused-by-flooding-major-danger-to-british-lives-engineers-warn</link>
      <description><p>Report says infrastructure such as electricity grids and communication networks are not adequately protected from the threat</p><p>Power cuts caused by flooding are a major danger to people’s lives in the UK and “could happen anywhere” because infrastructure such as electricity grids and communications networks are not adequately protected against the threat, according to <a href="http://www.raeng.org.uk/publications/reports/living-without-electricity">a new report</a>.</p><p>The finding, from the Royal Academy of Engineering, calls into question the UK’s preparedness for incidences of weather-related disasters, even as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/dec/09/cameron-government-rejected-flood-risk-warnings-from-climate-advisers">scientists and government advisers have warned that they will become more frequent</a>, owing to climate change.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/power-cuts-caused-by-flooding-major-danger-to-british-lives-engineers-warn">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>UK government spent £105,000 in legal fees on lost air pollution case</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/uk-government-spent-105000-in-legal-fees-on-lost-air-pollution-case</link>
      <description><p>Government is wasting time and taxpayers’ money as it faces a second court challenge over illegal air pollution, say green lawyers</p><p>The government spent at least £105,000 in legal costs while fighting and losing a court challenge over illegal levels of air pollution, according to <a href="https://www.whatdotheyknow.com/request/266057/response/679906/attach/3/RFI%207483%20response%20letter.pdf">data released through freedom of information rules</a>, and now faces further bills from a new case it is contesting.</p><p>ClientEarth, the environmental lawyers who defeated the government, say the taxpayers’ money should have been used instead for early and effective action to cut air pollution, which causes 40,000 early deaths a year, according to government figures. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/uk-government-spent-105000-in-legal-fees-on-lost-air-pollution-case">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Dyson could become next Tesla with its electric car, says expert</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/dysons-electric-car-development-could-become-the-next-tesla</link>
      <description><p>Filed patents show the British engineering firm may use solid-state batteries that could stretch electric car’s range to hundreds of miles and increase safety </p><p>Dyson could become the next Tesla motors as it develops a new electric car, according to a leading industry expert. Filed patents show the Dyson vehicle may use solid-state batteries, which would see the car’s range stretch to hundreds of miles and also be safer than current batteries.</p><p>In March, a government document revealed funding to help <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/23/dyson-developing-electric-car-government-documents">Dyson develop “a new battery electric vehicle”</a>. The company declined to comment but in 2015 it said it planned to invest £1bn in battery technology and in October it <a href="http://venturebeat.com/2015/10/19/dyson-acquires-sakti3-for-90m-to-help-commercialize-breakthrough-solid-state-battery-tech/">bought solid-state battery company, Sakti3, for $90m</a>, which founder Sir James Dyson said had “developed a breakthrough in battery technology”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/dysons-electric-car-development-could-become-the-next-tesla">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Google Images 'as good as fieldwork' for studying animal colour</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/google-images-as-good-as-fieldwork-for-studying-animal-colour</link>
      <description><p>Study of different colours in black bears, barn owls, black sparrowhawks and crows finds online images can substitute for costly fieldwork</p><p>Studying photographs of animals posted online by the general public has proven to be as valuable as traditional fieldwork in research on the locations of species that have evolved with different colours. </p><p>Colour polymorphism - the occurrence of two or more colour types in the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population">population</a> of a species - has long fascinated biologists. These different colour types often vary geographically, providing a useful way of studying how different colour morphs evolve.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/google-images-as-good-as-fieldwork-for-studying-animal-colour">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Heathrow to ban night flights as part of plan for third runway</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/heathrow-airport-ban-night-flights-plan-third-runway</link>
      <description><p>Airport will ban arrivals and departures before 5.30am, and support the launch of an independent noise authority</p><p>Heathrow has agreed to curb night flights if permission is granted for a third runway, as it announced measures it claimed met all the conditions set by the Airports Commission for its expansion plan.</p><p>As well as banning all arrivals and departures before 5.30am, the airport said it would support the introduction of an independent noise authority, and pledged not to add new capacity unless it can do so without delaying UK compliance with EU air quality limits.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/heathrow-airport-ban-night-flights-plan-third-runway">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/we-are-mortgaging-the-future-by-scrapping-zero-carbon-home-rules</link>
      <description><p>The UK government’s failure to build new homes that are energy efficient will see future generations dealing with our costly mistakes </p><p>From the Forth Bridge to our sewer system and the London Underground, we still rely on Victorian engineering every day in modern Britain. We all benefit from this inherited infrastructure, but we’re still paying the bills for the way it was built. </p><p>Our older homes are among the most energy-wasting the world. And as anyone who has lived in a draughty, single-glazed, Victorian terrace knows, they can be expensive to keep warm in winter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/we-are-mortgaging-the-future-by-scrapping-zero-carbon-home-rules">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/north-east-atlantic-mackerel-wins-back-sustainable-status</link>
      <description><p>Stocks at the centre of the ‘mackerel war’ regain eco-label after joint efforts by fishermen and regional ministers </p><p>North-east Atlantic mackerel has won back its status as a sustainably managed fish stock - after losing it at the height of the “mackerel war”.</p><p>An international coalition of more than 700 fishing boats from small coastal vessels to ocean-going trawlers has regained the “eco-label” for mackerel from the Marine Stewardship Council (MSC), which certifies well-managed fisheries.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/north-east-atlantic-mackerel-wins-back-sustainable-status">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Headlines 'exaggerated' climate link to sinking of Pacific islands</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/headlines-exaggerated-climate-link-to-sinking-of-pacific-islands</link>
      <description><p>Report’s author says many media outlets have misinterpreted the science by conflating sea-level rise with climate change </p><p>Links between climate change and the sinking of five islands in the Pacific Ocean have been exaggerated, the author of a widely reported new study has said.</p><p><a href="http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/11/5/054011">The report</a>, published on Friday, tracked the shapeshifting of 33 reef islands in the Solomon Islands between 1947 and 2014. It found that five had been washed away completely and six more had been severely eroded. The study blamed the loss on a combination of sea-level rise and high wave energy.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/headlines-exaggerated-climate-link-to-sinking-of-pacific-islands">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>One in five of world's plant species at risk of extinction</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/one-in-five-of-worlds-plant-species-at-risk-of-extinction</link>
      <description><p>Global report highlights threat to food security and medicine supplies but also reveals 2,000 new species are discovered each year</p><p>One in five of the world’s plant species is threatened with extinction, according to the first global assessment of flora, putting supplies of food and medicines at risk.</p><p>But the report also found that 2,000 new species of plant are discovered every year, raising hopes of new sources of food that are resilient to disease and climate change. New finds in 2015 included a giant insect-eating plant first spotted on Facebook and a 100-tonne tree hidden in an African forest.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/one-in-five-of-worlds-plant-species-at-risk-of-extinction">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p><a href="http://www.climatecentral.org/news/see-earths-temperature-spiral-toward-2c-20332">Climate Central</a>: A new graphic shows Earth’s temperatures spiralling toward the 2C global warming limit</p><p>The steady rise of Earth’s temperature as greenhouse gases accumulate in the atmosphere and trap more and more heat is sending the planet spiraling closer to the point where warming’s catastrophic consequences may be all but assured.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/see-earths-temperature-spiral-toward-2c-rise-graphic">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>People may be breathing in microplastics, health expert warns</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/people-may-be-breathing-in-microplastics-health-expert-warns</link>
      <description><p>Environmental health professor says microparticles of plastic, known to damage marine life, could be entering the air</p><p>People could be breathing in microparticles of plastic, according to a leading environmental health expert, with as yet unknown consequences on health.</p><p>Microplastics are known to be damaging to life in the oceans, with marine creatures mistaking them for food, and to be consumed by people eating seafood. But Frank Kelly, a professor of environmental health at King’s College London, told <a href="http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/environmental-audit-committee/inquiries/parliament-2015/environmental-impact-of-microplastics-15-16/">MPs investigating the issue</a> that the particles could be being inhaled too.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/people-may-be-breathing-in-microplastics-health-expert-warns">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Carbon dioxide emissions from US energy sector fall 12% since 2005</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/carbon-dioxide-emissions-united-states-coal-gas-energy-industry-decline</link>
      <description><p>The shift comes amid a decline in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/coal">use of coal</a> and increase in the use of natural gas to generate electricity, energy officials say</p><p>Carbon dioxide emissions from the US’s energy sector fell in 2015 and now stand at 12% below 2005 levels, a drop mainly driven by the continuing collapse of the coal industry.</p><p>Americans’ energy consumption resulted in the release of 5.2bn tons of CO<sub>2</sub> last year, <a href="http://www.eia.gov/totalenergy/data/monthly/pdf/mer.pdf">according to the US Energy Information Administration</a> (EIA), down from 5.4bn tons in 2014. The 12% cut since 2005 has come during a period in which the US economy has, adjusting for inflation, grown by 15%. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/carbon-dioxide-emissions-united-states-coal-gas-energy-industry-decline">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Satellite Eye on Earth: April 2016 – in pictures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/satellite-eye-on-earth-april-2016-in-pictures</link>
      <description><p>Iran’s salt desert, New Suez Canal and British astronaut Tim Peak’s snap of UK under an aurora were among the images captured by European Space Agency and Nasa satellites last month</p><p>Dasht-e Kavir, the swirling landscape of Iran’s salt desert, is reminiscent of an abstract painting. With temperatures reaching 50C in the summer, this area sees little precipitation, but runoff from mountains creates seasonal lakes and marshes. Extreme heat causes the water to evaporate, leaving behind clays and sand soils with a high concentration of minerals. The “brushstroke” patterns are geological layers eroded primarily by wind. Along the left side of the image we can see part of an area known as the “devil’s dunes” because it was believed to be haunted by evil spirits. This belief likely originated from its hostile conditions, and the early travellers who did attempt to cross it probably never returned due to starvation or dehydration. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/satellite-eye-on-earth-april-2016-in-pictures">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Could Brexit be the best thing for Europe’s wildlife? | Jules Howard</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/09/brexit-europe-wildlife-eu</link>
      <description>The EU has a reputation for legislating to protect nature, whereas the UK drags its heels. Without us, perhaps animals and their habitats might get a better deal<p>Nothing oozes status like a man with an endangered alligator lizard draped over his shoulder that he has bought illegally through a German reptile trade show. These are people not content with a pet <a href="http://www.beardeddragonguide.com/" title="">bearded dragon</a> or a pet <a href="http://fohn.net/corn-snake-pictures-facts/" title="">corn snake</a>. They want more. They want something no one else has, even if having it contributes to the extinction of these unusual lizards in the wild.</p><p>Thank goodness, then, that the Guardian <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/nov/11/lizard-traffickers-exploit-legal-loopholes-to-trade-at-worlds-biggest-fair" title="">exposed this illegal market</a> last year, and that the EU committed on Thursday to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/europe-to-crack-down-on-wildlife-smugglers-following-guardian-investigation" title="">tightening the loopholes</a> in the illegal trade of reptiles such as these beautiful endangered lizards. I’d like to say that Britain was a key part of this story, but our record on tackling wildlife crime isn’t brilliant. Although we talk the talk (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/feb/13/global-accord-illegal-wildlife-trade-london-46-nations" title="">remember this?</a>) in three out of the past four years the government has attempted to close our <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/jan/08/national-wildlife-crime-unit-endangered" title="">National Wildlife Crime Unit</a>, an important department for monitoring such things as illegal pet trade activity. Thankfully the EU forced us forward – on this issue at least.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/09/brexit-europe-wildlife-eu">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Malaysian palm giant, IOI, lost business after it was suspended from the Roundtable for Sustainable Palm Oil’s certification scheme over deforestation allegations in Indonesia</p><p>One of the world’s largest palm oil producers is suing the green body that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/sustainable-business/2016/apr/09/ioi-malaysian-palm-oil-company-unilever-mars-kellogg-rspo-deforestation">suspended its</a> sustainability certification last month because of allegations it had deforested Indonesian rainforests.</p><p>The Roundtable for Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO), a body set up by industry and NGOs to address environmental concerns about the commodity’s production, confirmed it had been served with a lawsuit by the Malaysian palm giant, IOI.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/top-palm-oil-producer-sues-green-group-over-deforestation-allegations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The false widow spider and the woodlouse</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/country-diary-false-widow-spider-woodlouse</link>
      <description><p><strong>Havant, Hampshire</strong> As I watched, a woodlouse blundered into a translucent tripline and the web vibrated</p><p>My gardening gloves had lain abandoned in the shed for several months as the cold, wet spring had thwarted any plans to plant out early crops. When I went to put them on they pulled away from the rough-planked shed wall with a sound like ripping Velcro. As I peeled off a candyfloss puff of cobweb, a rotund spider the size of my fingernail scuttled across the back of my hand and dropped to the floor.</p><p>A neighbour sauntered over after hearing me yelp. “Kill it,” he advised as we watched the arachnid squeeze into a crack in the wood behind its three-dimensional web. “That’s one of those venomous foreign spiders. They’re dangerous, I’ve seen the news …”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/13/country-diary-false-widow-spider-woodlouse">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Obama's methane rule an aggressive step toward tackling climate change</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/obama-methane-emissions-rule-oil-gas-climate-change</link>
      <description><p>White House announces new regulations to cut methane emissions – a climate pollutant – from the oil and gas industry almost in half </p><p>The Obama administration announced on Thursday new rules to cut methane emissions from the oil and gas industry almost in half – tackling a powerful climate pollutant in the president’s final months in the White House.</p><p>The rules, stronger than earlier proposals, are aimed at reducing methane emissions from the US by 40% to 45% over 2012 levels by 2025 by requiring companies to capture gas from oil wells, and find and plug pipeline leaks. America is currently the world’s largest oil and gas producer.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/obama-methane-emissions-rule-oil-gas-climate-change">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/true-north/2016/may/12/the-arsonists-of-fort-mcmurray-have-a-name</link>
      <description><p>Fossil fuel corporations are causing the climate change fuelling mega-fires – and they should be footing the bill for the devastation </p><p>As the fire that <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/10/canada-wildfire-fort-mcmurray-saved-alberta-premier">ravaged Fort McMurray</a> finally moves past the city, and the province tallies the heartbreaking damage, a search will begin to discover the source of the destruction.</p><p>Investigators will comb the nearby forests for clues, tracing the fire’s path to what they call its “point of origin.” They’ll interview witnesses, collect satellite imagery, and rule out natural causes—much like the work of detectives.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/true-north/2016/may/12/the-arsonists-of-fort-mcmurray-have-a-name">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Three passengers in their 50s and 60s remain in hospital following the blaze on the 25-metre catamaran, which forced 46 passengers to abandon ship</p><p>A boat fire off the southern tip of the Great Barrier Reef that forced more than 40 tourists to escape into life rafts is believed to have started in the ship’s engine.</p><p>The now-sunken Spirit of 1770 <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/2016/may/11/tourists-rescued-from-boat-that-caught-fire-off-great-barrier-reef-island">caught fire in waters 18km off the coastal community called Town of 1770 on Wednesday afternoon, close to Lady Musgrave island</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/great-barrier-reef-boat-fire-police-say-blaze-may-have-started-in-engine">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Oil firms have 10 years to change strategy or face 'short, brutish end'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/oil-firms-environment-energy-climate-change</link>
      <description><p>Business models employed by multinationals such as Shell and BP are no longer fit for purpose, warns energy expert</p><p>International oil companies such as Shell and BP must completely change their business model or face a “nasty, brutish and short” end within 10 years, one of Britain’s most influential energy experts has warned.</p><p>Paul Stephens, a fellow at Chatham House thinktank, said in <a href="https://www.chathamhouse.org/publication/international-oil-companies-death-old-business-model">a research paper</a> the oil “majors” were no longer fit for purpose – hit by low crude prices, tightening climate change regulations and their own wrongheaded strategies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/may/05/oil-firms-environment-energy-climate-change">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/22/zac-goldsmith-backs-fossil-fuel-divestment-movement-london-mayor</link>
      <description><p>Tory London mayoral candidate supports pulling City Hall’s fund out of oil, coal and gas companies if elected</p><p>Zac Goldsmith has backed the fossil fuel divestment movement and said he would pursue efforts to pull London City Hall’s pension fund out of investments in oil, coal and gas if he was elected mayor.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p>The Conservative mayoral candidate’s support for moving the £4.8bn London Pension Authority Fund (LPFA) out of fossil fuel investments is at odds with Boris Johnson, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/may/13/boris-johnson-rejects-london-motion-on-fossil-fuel-divestment">who last year rejected a motion calling for divestment</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/22/zac-goldsmith-backs-fossil-fuel-divestment-movement-london-mayor">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>EU dropped climate policies after BP threat of oil industry 'exodus'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/20/eu-dropped-climate-policies-after-bp-threat-oil-industry-exodus</link>
      <description><p>Oil giant warned industry would pull out of EU if laws to cut pollution and speed clean energy take up were passed, letter obtained by the Guardian reveals</p><p>The EU abandoned or weakened key proposals for new environmental protections after receiving a letter from a top BP executive which warned of an exodus of the oil industry from Europe if the proposals went ahead.</p><p>In the 10-page letter, the company predicted in 2013 that a mass industry flight would result if laws to regulate tar sands, cut power plant pollution and accelerate the uptake of renewable energy were passed, because of the extra costs and red tape they allegedly entailed.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/20/eu-dropped-climate-policies-after-bp-threat-oil-industry-exodus">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>March temperature smashes 100-year global record</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/15/march-temperature-smashes-100-year-global-record</link>
      <description><p>Average global temperature was 1.07C hotter - beating last month’s previous record increase</p><p>The global temperature in March has shattered a century-long record and by the greatest margin yet seen for any month.<br></p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2016/mar/14/february-breaks-global-temperature-records-by-shocking-amount">February was far above the long-term average</a> globally, driven largely by climate change, and was described by scientists as a “shocker” and signalling “a kind of climate emergency”. But <a href="http://ds.data.jma.go.jp/tcc/tcc/products/gwp/temp/mar_wld.html">data released by the Japan Meteorological Agency</a> (JMA) shows that March was even hotter.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/15/march-temperature-smashes-100-year-global-record">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Norway’s sovereign wealth fund divests from energy companies that derive more than 30% of revenues from coal, on ethical grounds</p><p>Norway’s sovereign wealth fund, the world’s biggest, has excluded 52 coal-related companies in line with new ethical guidelines barring it from investing in such groups, Norway’s central bank said on Thursday.</p><p>The move was seen as a sign of the growing influence investors wield in the fight against climate change.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/15/worlds-biggest-wealth-fund-excludes-52-coal-related-groups">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Coal made its best case against climate change, and lost | Dana Nuccitelli</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/11/coal-made-its-best-case-against-climate-change-and-lost</link>
      <description><p>A Minnesota judge found the preponderance of evidence did not favor coal industry climate science denial<br></p><p>Peabody Energy, the world’s largest private sector coal company (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/13/worlds-largest-coal-producer-files-for-bankruptcy-protection">now bankrupt</a>), recently faced off against environmental groups in a Minnesota court case. The case was to determine whether the State of Minnesota should continue using its exceptionally low established estimates of the ‘social cost of carbon’, or whether it should adopt higher federal estimates. <br></p><p>The social cost of carbon is an estimate of how much the damages from carbon pollution cost society via climate change damages. In theory, it represents how much the price of fossil fuels should increase to reflect their true costs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/11/coal-made-its-best-case-against-climate-change-and-lost">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Deep sea microbes may be key to oceans’ climate change feedback | Howard Lee</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/06/deep-sea-microbes-may-be-key-to-oceans-climate-change-feedback</link>
      <description><p>Microbe populations make up 11-31% of living matter in the ocean seabed, but decline significantly as oceans warm<br></p><p>Microbes are hardly the poster-children of climate change, but they have far more impact than polar bears on Earth’s carbon cycle – and therefore on our climate. A new study published Friday in <a href="http://advances.sciencemag.org/content/2/4/e1500961"><em>Science Advances</em></a> finds that seabed bacteria and archaea (which look like bacteria but have very different genetics and biochemistry) are sensitive to climate. Because their habitat covers 65% of the entire globe, they form a huge part of the biosphere and are important in the regulation of carbon in the deep ocean, which affects long-term climate change.</p><p>The microbes in question are packed together in the top 15 centimeters of the deep ocean seabed, like rush hour commuters in a city metro, up to a million times more abundant than in the sunless ocean water, or buried in deeper layers of seabed sediments. Their city-like crowding is fueled by a sparse sordid snow of excrement and microscopic dead bodies from life in the upper ocean, far above them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/06/deep-sea-microbes-may-be-key-to-oceans-climate-change-feedback">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Tesla chief says educating the public on climate issues is essential in countering oil and gas lobby’s influence over big political decisions, <a href="http://www.edie.net">reports Edie.net</a></p><p>Tesla’s chief executive Elon Musk has accused politicians of bowing to the “unrelenting and enormous” lobbying power of the fossil fuel industry, warning that a global “revolt” may be needed to accelerate the transition to more sustainable energy and transport systems.<br></p><p>Speaking at the <a href="http://worldenergyinnovationforum.com/">World Energy Innovation Forum</a> at the Tesla Factory in California on Wednesday, Musk claimed that traditional vehicles and energy sources will continue to hold a competitive edge against greener alternatives due to the vast amounts of subsidies they receive.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/elon-musk-we-need-a-revolt-against-the-fossil-fuel-industry">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How safe does protected status keep the world's national parks?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/how-safe-does-protected-status-keep-the-worlds-national-parks</link>
      <description><p>Protected areas and habitats are being downgraded and delisted so often, to accommodate mining, logging or population growth, the problem even has its own acronym.<a href="http://e360.yale.edu/feature/how_nations_are_chipping_away_their_protected_lands/2989/"> Environment 360 reports</a></p><p>It’s the saddest truism in wildlife conservation: When politicians announce that they are setting aside precious habitat “in perpetuity”, what they really mean is until somebody else wants the land. </p><p>Protected areas now get reopened so often under the pressure of population and economic growth that the trend has spawned an acronym, PADDD, for “protected area downgrading, downsizing, and degazettement.” There’s also a web site, <a href="http://www.padddtracker.org/">PADDDtracker.org</a>, jointly maintained by the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) and Conservation International. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/how-safe-does-protected-status-keep-the-worlds-national-parks">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why did the death of Cecil the lion cause such an uproar?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/why-did-death-of-a-single-lion-cecil-cause-such-an-uproar</link>
      <description><p>Analysis of the huge news and online response to his death could offer conservationists an opportunity to turn the ‘Cecil moment’ into a ‘Cecil movement’, reports <a href="http://conservationmagazine.org/2016/05/cecil-media-reaction/">Conservation Magazine</a></p><p>When the story of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/cecil-the-lion">Cecil the lion</a>’s death at the hands of an American hunter hit the media, the global response was “the largest reaction in the history of wildlife conservation,” according to a new paper. Researchers from <a href="http://wildcru.org/">Oxford’s Wildlife Conservation </a><a href="http://wildcru.org/">Research </a><a href="http://wildcru.org/">Unit</a> (or WildCRU, the same organization that had tracked the lion since 2009) analyzed the traditional and social media response to the hunting incident. They found that a combination of elements in the story may have made it go viral in a different way than the average internet sensation. And conservationists may subsequently have a golden opportunity to transform the “Cecil moment” into a “Cecil movement”.</p><p>To recap the sequence of events around Cecil’s death: Around 10pm on 1 July 2015, a hunter from Minnesota named Walter Palmer sent an arrow into the side of a 13-year-old male African lion nicknamed ‘Cecil’ on privately owned property outside of Zimbabwe’s Hwange National Park. This arrow failed to kill the beast, but the second one, shot some 11 hours later, did.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/why-did-death-of-a-single-lion-cecil-cause-such-an-uproar">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Scientists are figuring out the keys to convincing people about global warming | Dana Nuccitelli</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/04/scientists-are-figuring-out-the-keys-to-convincing-people-about-global-warming</link>
      <description><p>Understanding the greenhouse effect, the expert consensus, and that humans are causing global warming are gateways to support for climate policies<br></p><p><a href="http://climatecommunication.yale.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/Politics-and-Global-Warming-Spring-2016.pdf">The latest survey data</a> from Yale and George Mason universities underscores the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/apr/28/can-the-republican-party-solve-its-science-denial-problem">partisan divide on climate science denial</a> – 73% of Americans realize that global warming is happening, including 71% of liberal/moderate Republicans, but the average is dragged down by the mere 47% of conservative Republicans who answer this question correctly. On the bright side, this is a big improvement from the 28% of conservative Republicans who realized global warming was happening just two years ago.</p><p>Similarly, 56% of Americans realize global warming is mostly caused by humans, including 49% of liberal/moderate Republicans, but the number is again dragged down by the 26% of conservative Republicans correctly answering this question. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-consensus-97-per-cent/2016/may/04/scientists-are-figuring-out-the-keys-to-convincing-people-about-global-warming">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>How forest management helps lay the conditions for wildfires | Karl Mathiesen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/how-forest-management-helps-lay-the-conditions-for-wildfires</link>
      <description><p>As flames rip through Alberta, we look at how putting out small fires can help to fuel increasingly catastrophic events as our climate gets hotter and drier</p><p>By dousing small, regular fires, forest managers are creating the conditions for cataclysmic events, scientists have said.</p><p>Fires in temperate forests are generally <a href="http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2015/150714/ncomms8537/full/ncomms8537.html">increasing in size and area</a>. This is partly because of climate change. Fire seasons in many parts of the world are getting longer and drier. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/how-forest-management-helps-lay-the-conditions-for-wildfires">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why the Paris climate change goals may already be slipping beyond reach</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/22/paris-climate-agreement-united-nations</link>
      <description><p>World leaders convened at the UN this week in support of the historic deal, but epic challenges lie ahead if the promises of Paris are going to be put into action</p><p>World leaders have failed to come to grips with the epic challenge of phasing out fossil fuels and running the entire global economy almost entirely on clean energy by the middle of this century, experts said this week.</p><p>While more than 170 countries <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/22/paris-climate-deal-set-signed-record-number-states-un">converged at the United Nations on Friday</a> to demonstrate their support for the landmark deal to fight climate change reached at Paris last December, economists and scientists warned the accord’s goal of keeping temperatures below 1.5-2C may already be slipping beyond reach.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/22/paris-climate-agreement-united-nations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>All 93 vehicles tested in Germany and UK exceeded EU-set limits on air quality and pollution in real-world situation</p><p>The air pollution scandal that hit front pages around the world last year with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/ng-interactive/2015/sep/23/volkswagen-emissions-scandal-explained-diesel-cars">VW’s admission it had been cheating emissions tests</a> has got much bigger.</p><p>A UK government-sponsored trial launched in the wake of the VW revelations has found that every single one of the diesel-fuelled vehicles tested had <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/apr/21/all-top-selling-cars-break-emissions-limits-in-real-world-tests">higher emissions of nitrogen oxide pollutants</a> than permitted under EU laws.       <title>Is it safe to dump Fukushima waste into the sea? | Karl Mathiesen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/13/is-it-safe-to-dump-fukushima-waste-into-the-sea</link>
      <description><p>Japan has called for hundreds of thousands tonnes of irradiated water from the nuclear plant to be released into the Pacific Ocean. Karl Mathiesen looks at the potential impacts</p><p>More than 1,000 tanks brimming with irradiated water stand inland from the Fukushima nuclear plant. Each day 300 tonnes of water are pumped through Fukushima’s ruined reactors to keep them cool. As the <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/mar/10/fukushima-operator-dump-contaminated-water-pacific">water washes through the plant</a> it collects a slew of radioactive particles.</p><p>The company that owns the plant – The Tokyo Electric Power Company (Tepco) - has deployed filtration devices that have stripped very dangerous isotopes of strontium and caesium from the flow. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/13/is-it-safe-to-dump-fukushima-waste-into-the-sea">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Analysis of the figures show Port Talbot may actually have been profiting from efforts to reduce carbon emissions</p><p>There was a slew of comment over the weekend regarding the role that Britain’s carbon reduction efforts played in Tata Steel’s decision to sell off its UK operations.</p><p>A <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-3519996/DAILY-MAIL-COMMENT-crown-jewels-lose.html#ixzz44sOQV3XT ">Daily Mail editorial</a> called “the crippling green taxes imposed by Ed Miliband’s Climate Change Act in 2008” a “monstrous handicap” that had driven the steelworks and its 5,000 workers over the precipice. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/apr/05/green-policies-are-not-responsible-for-the-tata-steel-crisis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/media-network/2016/may/12/craigslist-uk-food-waste-sharing-economy-apps</link>
      <description><p>A raft of apps are aiming to recycle cosmetically challenged perishables and stop £5bn worth of food ending up in landfill</p><p>Where most people see a bruised banana, Saasha Celestial-One and Tessa Cook see a chance to share.       <description><p>Severe weather and dangerous swells hamper search for 2.5m pygmy or dwarf sperm whale found at Logans Beach</p><p>Wildlife officers are trying to find a small and rare whale that was found stranded at a Victorian beach on Monday evening, however their search efforts are being hampered by severe weather and dangerous swells.</p><p>The adult whale, about 2.5m long, was found at Logans Beach in Victoria’s south-west and rescuers believe it to be either a pygmy sperm whale or a dwarf sperm whale. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/wildlife-officers-search-for-rare-whale-stranded-on-victorian-beach">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/red-squirrel-leprosy-study-brownsea-island</link>
      <description><p>Researchers to investigate how disease is passed between red squirrels, whose numbers have declined drastically<br></p><p>Wildlife experts have launched a research project on an island off the south coast of England to better understand how British red squirrels are affected by a form of leprosy.</p><p>The study on <a href="http://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/brownsea-island I">Brownsea Island</a> will investigate how the disease is passed between red squirrels, whose numbers have declined drastically, and how conservationists can help control its spread.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/09/red-squirrel-leprosy-study-brownsea-island">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Microsculpture: hidden beauty of the bugs beneath our feet</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/08/microsculpture-exhibition-insects-photography-levon-biss</link>
      <description>When photographer Levon Biss turned his lens on the insects his son was collecting in the garden, it opened up a miniature world in which art meets science to dazzling effect<p>Two years ago, exhausted by the frantic pressures of commercial portraiture, photographer <a href="http://www.levonbiss.com/" title="">Levon Biss</a> was searching for a way to relax. His son Sebastian, then six, found the answer in their back garden. “My boy likes insects,” says Biss. “He’s always in the garden trying to find them and play with them. I started shooting insects he’d caught, so that he could see them clearly and be proud of finding them.” Making detailed portraits of insect specimens proved to be the perfect antidote to the trigger-happy, “disposable” photography that Biss feels is the current fashion. “I wanted a project that made me think, that was a challenge,” he says, and he gradually developed a technique so specialised and laborious, only a photographer of extreme patience and dedication could sustain it.</p><p>First, the pinned insect is mounted on an adapted microscope-stand in front of a camera with a macro lens. Biss then divides the insect into 30 sections, to be photographed separately at close range. “When you get to this magnification,” he explains, “the depth of field is so shallow, there’s only a minute plane of focus.” To render, for instance, a whole wing-casing in focus, it must be photographed around 750 times, with each photo taken 10 microns apart. Those 750 images are then painstakingly compiled into a composite, using a variety of sophisticated software.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/08/microsculpture-exhibition-insects-photography-levon-biss">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Australia quietly adds 49 species to threatened and endangered lists</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/07/australia-quietly-adds-49-species-to-threatened-and-endangered-lists</link>
      <description><p>Brush-tailed bettong, three-toed snake-tooth skink, swift parrot and types of orchid and albatross listed</p><p>Nearly 50 new species of flora and fauna have been added without fanfare to the federal government’s list of threatened species, including nine that are critically endangered.</p><p>Among the species to be added <a href="http://www.environment.gov.au/cgi-tmp/publiclistchanges.17a4572b13bc386e313d.html">to the list</a> under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act were the brush-tailed bettong (endangered), the three-toed snake-tooth skink (vulnerable), the swift parrot (upgraded from endangered to critically endangered), and several types of orchid and albatross.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/07/australia-quietly-adds-49-species-to-threatened-and-endangered-lists">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/wildlife">Wildlife</category>

      <description><p><strong>Jonathan and Angela Scott: </strong>After the ivory burn, it’s up to all of us to make sure the pledges made there are honoured </p><p>People have always been smitten by the beauty of elephant ivory, as I discovered for myself while travelling overland from London to Johannesburg in 1974. </p><p>I am not exactly sure where I bought the small ivory carving that would haunt me in years to come. I think it was Kisangani (formerly Stanleyville), 2000 km upstream from the mouth of the mighty Congo River, home during the 1880s to Mohammed Bin Alfan Murjebi alias Tipu Tip, the infamous Zanzibari who traded ivory and slaves. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/africa-wild/2016/may/06/burning-the-ivory-is-just-the-beginning">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Amazon and eBay hosted ads for banned invasive species</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/amazon-and-ebay-hosting-ads-for-banned-invasive-species</link>
      <description><p>Unregulated traders are using the sites to sell some of the world’s most invasive plants, with potentially devastating impacts on ecosystems</p><p>Amazon and eBay appear to have openly broken the law by hosting listings to ship banned invasive species to the UK, the Guardian can reveal.</p><p>Both <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/apr/21/illegal-trade-in-endangered-wildlife-thriving-on-ebay-despite-controls">eBay</a> and <a href="http://eia-global.org/news-media/amazoncom-is-selling-thousands-of-ivory-items-as-the-slaughter-of-africas">Amazon</a> have previously been criticised for hosting ivory traders, but the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) rates invasive species as a more significant threat to biodiversity than poaching for animal parts. In February, the <a href="https://www.cbd.int/doc/meetings/sbstta/sbstta-20/official/sbstta-20-07-en.pdf">CBD said</a> there was an “urgent need” to control the vast, unregulated network of online traders who buy and sell these pests across the globe.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/amazon-and-ebay-hosting-ads-for-banned-invasive-species">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/06/mariana-trench-live-feed-engrossing-viewing-from-deepest-place-on-earth</link>
      <description><p>Rare footage from 11km underwater streams on Youtube from National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration vessel</p><p>A live video feed of the Mariana trench – the deepest place on Earth – is proving engrossing viewing for those above sea level.</p><p>The Mariana trench plunges about 11km (seven miles) deep under the Pacific – further down than the summit of Mount Everest is above sea level.     <item>
      <title>For butterflies, timing is everything</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/butterflies-timing-everything</link>
      <description><p><strong>Patrick Barkham </strong>on how the late flowering of food species can spell disaster for butterflies emerging after winter</p><p>For me, spring truly begins when the first <a href="http://butterfly-conservation.org/50-606/orange-tip.html">male orange tip</a> passes on its ceaseless jinking search for females. It was late this year, and this small white butterfly with unmistakable orange tips to its wings only materialised in my garden last week.</p><p>What worried me was not its tardiness but its food plant’s. The <a href="http://www.wildlifetrusts.org/species/garlic-mustard">garlic mustard</a> on which superbly-camouflaged (and occasionally cannibalistic) orange tip caterpillars feed (they also devour that lovely spring flower, lady’s smock, in damper spots) had barely sprouted any leaves last week.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/butterflies-timing-everything">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Europe to crack down on wildlife smugglers to protect rare lizard species</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/europe-to-crack-down-on-wildlife-smugglers-following-guardian-investigation</link>
      <description><p>EU proposal seeks to close a legal loophole allowing the sale of endangered lizards in Europe after a Guardian article revealed the scale of the problem</p><p>Europe has moved to close a loophole that allows wildlife smugglers to trade in several endangered lizard species, after <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/nov/11/lizard-traffickers-exploit-legal-loopholes-to-trade-at-worlds-biggest-fair">revelations by the Guardian</a> about the scale of the problem.</p><p>An <a href="http://ec.europa.eu/environment/cites/events_en.htm#cop17">EU</a><a href="http://ec.europa.eu/environment/cites/events_en.htm#cop17"> proposal</a> to strictly regulate the trade in arboreal alligator lizards (<em>Abronia</em>), backed by Mexico, will be debated at the Convention on international trade in endangered species (Cites) conference, which opens in Johannesburg this autumn.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/05/europe-to-crack-down-on-wildlife-smugglers-following-guardian-investigation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>World's carbon dioxide concentration teetering on the point of no return</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/worlds-carbon-dioxide-concentration-teetering-on-the-point-of-no-return</link>
      <description><p>Future in which global concentration of CO2 is permanently above 400 parts per million looms </p><p>The world is hurtling towards an era when global concentrations of carbon dioxide never again dip below the 400 parts per million (ppm) milestone, as two important measuring stations sit on the point of no return.</p><p>The news comes as one important atmospheric measuring station at Cape Grim in Australia is poised on the verge of 400ppm for the first time. Sitting in a region with stable CO2 concentrations, once that happens, it will never get a reading below 400ppm.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/11/worlds-carbon-dioxide-concentration-teetering-on-the-point-of-no-return">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/climate-change">Climate change</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/australia-news/australia-news">Australia news</category>

      <title>Which are the world's two most polluted cities  – and why?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/which-are-the-worlds-two-most-polluted-cities-and-why</link>
      <description><p>Two cities – one in Iran and another in Nigeria – can claim title because WHO measures pollution in two different ways</p><p>The new WHO database of worldwide air pollution measures it in two different ways, and as a result two cities – one in Iran and another in Nigeria – can lay claim to the unenviable title of world’s most polluted city.</p><p>It all comes down to which minute particles, or particulate matter (PM), in the air are being measured. These particles are between 2.5 and 10 microns in diameter, roughly 30 times smaller than the width of a human hair. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/which-are-the-worlds-two-most-polluted-cities-and-why">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Five Pacific islands lost to rising seas as climate change hits</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/five-pacific-islands-lost-rising-seas-climate-change</link>
      <description><p>Six more islands have large swaths of land, and villages, washed into sea as coastline of Solomon Islands eroded and overwhelmed</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/headlines-exaggerated-climate-link-to-sinking-of-pacific-islands">Headlines ‘exaggerated’ climate link to sinking of Pacific islands</a></li></ul><p>Five tiny Pacific islands have disappeared due to rising seas and erosion, a discovery thought to be the first scientific confirmation of the impact of climate change on coastlines in the Pacific, according to Australian researchers.<br></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/mar/30/sea-levels-set-to-rise-far-more-rapidly-than-expected">Sea levels set to 'rise far more rapidly than expected'</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/10/five-pacific-islands-lost-rising-seas-climate-change">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Eastbourne a surprise name among UK's most polluted towns and cities</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/eastbourne-a-surprise-name-among-uks-most-polluted-towns-and-cities</link>
      <description><p>Port Talbot seems obvious, but World Health Organisation data shows south coast town registers high levels of two tiny types of particulate pollution <br></p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/air-pollution-how-does-it-affect-you">Air pollution: how does it affect you? </a></li></ul><p>It’s perhaps no surprise that Port Talbot, home to one of Europe’s biggest steelworks with thousands of tonnes of iron ore imported to its docks every year, tops the list of the UK’s most polluted towns and cities. </p><p>But Eastbourne, home to the women’s tennis tournament and located at the end of the South Downs national park, is not an obvious candidate for the top 10 of the worst UK towns and cities for two tiny types of particulate pollution. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2016/may/12/eastbourne-a-surprise-name-among-uks-most-polluted-towns-and-cities">Continue reading...</a></description>
